How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not

very practical, improved presentation skills during the course and discussed real-life public health issues with experts

Some sessions were stronger than others. Since most were guest lectures, it was usual for the lecturer to talk for 45-50 minutes, leaving little time for the students to give their presentations and little time for discussions with the class. While the invited lecturer is undoubtedly an expert in their field, the lack of discussion time available is a problem and should be corrected.
Really interesting and fostered open discussion about many public health problems.
Fine overview of the landmark epi/public health efforts and topics.
Every weekly topic is interesting. Final projects are great opportunities for students to actually pay attention to and enroll in solving public health issues.
You really learned about many topics in public health in details. Each time a speaker in the related field was invited and they shared many knowledges and personal experiences with the students.

One thing I did not appreciate about the course was changing the final presentation schedule one week in advance. I understand the reasons behind it but given that I am an APMPH student whose clinical time/family time gets planned weeks in advance, it is hard to make last minute adjustments.

Secondly, I think some topics can be cut out from the course (lead session for instance) to allow time for global health to occur on two separate weeks, with perhaps different guests rather than a 4 hour extravaganza. 

The time for presentations and perhaps number of presentations can be dramatically changed without the course suffering. While most of the articles were pertinent, I think reading one less and presenting one less would still have allowed for good discussion to happen. In fact, I argue that having time for discussion that was not rushed would have improved the course significantly.
Excellent course but might be hard if you go wrong direction.

Strength:The instructor invited expert from different areas, which makes the lecture quite interesting
Weakness: extended class time almost every class meeting
This course was more like a journal club. Some of the weeks were very interesting, but other weeks, not so much. I would have prefer more lectures and less student presentations.
Course is a seminar, so lots of guest speakers. The student presentations were variable, and some of them had too much information than was necessary.

Before starting, I was thinking this course would be about significant people public health people. Although the topics were interesting, most of them were overlapping with the other courses' topics that I took this semester. I cannot say that I've learned much. I liked the guest lecturers though. The Grand Challenge proposal was stressful but also was joyful. But I wish it was more clear in terms of the steps that we need to follow. Main problem of this class was nothing was clear until the very last minute. We were expected to present to two presentations for example, but it turned out that nobody knows it because we were not informed. As a student, I wish to be notified more systematically and timely. One last thing about this course was the students; majority of the class was not paying attention to the lecturers and presenters which I found so disrespectful and I believe one of the reasons for this distraction was the timing of the class. Everyone was so tired already and it was not easy to listen with a full concentration till 7 pm.
I dont like this course since it doesnt help me I the way I need.
good for understanding the common sense in public health
This was an excellent course with a fun final project and presentation.
good

Strengths: highlighted key themes, excellent course organization
Weaknesses:  (1) no breaks in a 5-7pm course (maybe just a 5min intentional break); (2) lack of time for later presentations could be solved by putting all presentations back-to-back before incorporating discussions
great
strength: let us read more papers. Know how to write proposals. Enhance our presentation ability.
The course covers information for various areas in public health.

Interesting class. 
The project or homework is not appropriate to evaluate what I have learned.

I understand this course is required for YSPH to retain its accreditation however, for students who are at Yale to become researchers, this course does not particularly serve them. It does expose students to a breadth of people and literature, spanning the public health field, however, the overall lack of critical methodology, time spent reading publications and listening to professors of unrelated topic areas, and the final project, do not serve research-based students very well.
good

Strengths
Dr Ko
The Gates challenge
The weekly assignments which force us to read the articles

Weaknesses
None  I can think of

The course is quite good and touches upon all areas of public health that are relevant for our careers. I would introduce more environmental health and toxicology issues instead of many social and behavioral topics.
very smart and focused, helpful and guidance was amazing
Dr Ko solicited good participation and critical questions from us when presenting and during discussions.
The instructor is very nice and offers useful feedback with regard to projects. Very encouraging as well.
Very enthusiastic about this work, and about the course.
He is an excellent instructor. He offered to discuss projects with students and provided useful suggestions. I greatly appreciate it.
Dr. Ko is a very responsible instructor. He encouraged us to think more about global health issues, and gave us timely feedback on the final project.

I think Dr. Ko was excellent in discussing comments and presentations for the Gates Challenges.
His moderating style was very hands off, and so I felt that the guest speakers controlled and taught each of the classes. I would have appreciated more direction from Dr. Ko towards the guest speakers.
Excellent instructor
He was a friendly guy with a lot of feedback on our proposals.
Nice professor, open to talking to students, gives good feedback.
Prof. Ko helped us a lot about our Gates project.
Excellent
Sometimes the reading response questions do not make sense to me
Passionate, good at conveying knowledge

Dr. Ko was extremely knowledgeable and a wealth of information on public health and global health issues. He was a pleasure to speak to and always willing to help advise students. I am grateful for all his help throughout the semester!
good

Provides practical insights melding his clinical with public health experience
- His two main lectures were highlights of the course; would have appreciated more lectures from him.
Prof. Ko is very inspiring.
intriguing
The professor gives lots of advice to prepare for the final Gates Challenge.

Very passionate about his own work. 
Does not listen to or trust the students' knowledge sometimes.

Dr. Ko is an instructor who, in challenging dogmas with interrogating questions, wants students to learn. However, his weakness lies in his inability to shift his own paradigm when met with an opposing student paradigm.
good
Great instructor. Challenged us to think critically
very practical, improved presentation skills during the course and discussed real-life public health issues with experts
Reading responses, student presentations, and group midterm and final project were time intensive but overall good in depth look at variety of fields in public health.
Really interesting course where you can learn a lot without a huge time commitment
A good capstone for those interested in getting a good overview of the field, without a ton of work.
It is a great course for students in public health to be more familiar with public problems around the world together with some thoughts on how to solve those problems.
A very good course for students who want to learn about many important topics in public health. I would recommend it.

Course looking at the hot topics in public health, some massive ones, some avantgarde ones, some you will love some you will hate. Gates Challenge style proposal at the end fun and not a ton of work, but reading responses weekly somewhat tedious.
Yes, as a capstone it was an interesting course to take.
I will absolutely recommend
This course is more relevant for students in the MS biostats and not the MPH program.
Course is a seminar, so really just a lot of guest lecturers. Very broad topics from epi to obesity to global health.
No I wont since I feel it is somewhat useless
Good introduction to common sense in public health

This class will cover the critical topics affecting public health and forces you to create an intervention which you must defend in a "Shark Tank" presentation. It is very practical and an absolute must for anyone considering a career in public health!
good

Excellent overview of public health and the challenges it faces today
- very practical deliverable at the end with grand challenge proposal
- would have preferred more engaging lecturing styles by guest lectures
Yes, I would recommend it.
recommend. Step one for PhD students
This class gives a good overview for key topics in public health.
It is ok, would recommend

This course is a survey of public health topics and research areas. I would recommend this course to a student who does not have an extensive public health background and wishes to learn about the field as a whole. This course is not appropriate for students who have a specific research focus, and ongoing research projects, as its 2-hour per/week meeting period, and papers/homework are not a productive way to spend time.
good
Good class. You learn about a variety of fields in public health .Workload is not too bad
I definitely recommend this course, especially for a fellow student without a background in public health from a prior MPH or graduate degree.
